awd_abstract_narration:
The San Diego Nanotechnology Infrastructure (SDNI) site of the NNCI at the University of California at San Diego offers access to a broad spectrum of nanofabrication and characterization instrumentation and expertise that enable and accelerate cutting edge scientific research, proof-of-concept demonstration, device and system prototyping, product development, and technology translation.  Nanotechnology is the cornerstone of many industry sectors and a rich source for scientific discoveries and innovations.  Using nanotechnologies, scientists are likely to find solutions for the most important challenges in health, communications, energy, and environment.  Nanotechnology is multidisciplinary by nature and requires highly sophisticated tools and deep expertise, often unavailable or unaffordable by individual research labs and businesses. The SDNI site will offer state-of-the-art knowhow, tools, and services of nanotechnologies to all interested users across the nation in a user friendly, timely, and cost effective manner. The site will also become a nanotechnology provider to create and develop new nanotechnologies and bring them to its users. The goals of the site are to serve a large number of academic, industrial, and government users, to transfer enabling nanotechnologies from research laboratories to the general user community, to educate and train future generations of scientists and engineers in nanotechnology, and to bring nanoscaled research experience to college students and K-12 students, especially underrepresented minority students, to prepare them for STEM careers. 

The SDNI site will build upon the existing Nano3 user facility and leverage additional specialized resources and expertise at the University of California at San Diego. The SDNI site is committed to broadening and further diversifying its already substantial user base. The proposed strategic goals include: (i) providing infrastructure that enables transformative research and education through open, affordable access to the nanofabrication and nanocharacterization tools and an expert staff capable of working with users to adapt and develop new capabilities, with emphasis in the areas of NanoBioMedicine, NanoPhotonics, and NanoMagnetism; (ii) accelerating the translation of discoveries and new nanotechnologies to the marketplace; and (iii) coordinating with other NNCI sites to provide uninterrupted service and creative solutions to meet evolving user needs. Significant growth is anticipated in the number and variety of local and regional users in the academic, government, and industrial sectors.   Discoveries made by users of the SDNI site have the potential to create transformative change in fields as diverse as medicine, information technology, transportation, homeland security, and environmental science, leading to improved healthcare, faster communications, safer transit, and cleaner water and air. To develop a more diverse and productive scientific workforce, the SDNI site will expand undergraduate and graduate training programs including REU opportunities to train 900 students over five years. Through an RET program and other activities, the site will work to increase the number of students from underrepresented minority groups who pursue studies and, ultimately, careers in STEM disciplines.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
San Diego Nanotechnology Infrastructure (SDNI), located at UCSD campus, has supported a wide range of nanotechnologies for research and development, education, and commercialization. Its facility is especially focused on four nanotechnology subareas: nano/meso/metamaterials, nanobiomedicine, nanophotonics, and nanomagnetics based on UCSD?s research strengths in these areas.  SDNI offers unique tool sets, skills, technical support, mentorship, and services to produce a myriad of innovative materials and devices that will help the nation to gain competitive advantages in the areas of next generation semiconductor technologies, artificial intelligence (AI), advanced manufacturing, quantum information science (QIS), 5G/6G communications, and convergence research with profound and lasting societal impact. To enhancing science and engineering through diversity and to help develop a diverse scientific workforce, SDNI has developed an extensive outreach and education program to promote STEM.

Despite the impact of the Covid pandemic, SDNI has been successful in servicing over 600 academic and industrial users from more than 200 PI groups and companies. SDNI has implemented special programs to support small businesses and train the work forces, making important contributions to the local and national economy.

SDNI has become the central place that enables fundamental and applied research in areas of the nation?s high priority. It has also contributed, in a significant way, to translational research and commercialization of innovative technologies. For fundamental research, we helped the Berkeley team to demonstrate the first quantum Hall coherent light sources with designed orbital angular momenta.  In applied research, we supported the groundbreaking work of an integrated, multimodal physical/biochemical wearable sensor demonstrated by scientists from UCSD Center for Wearable Sensors.  For technology advancement, we worked with engineers from TSMC and Stanford to develop cutting edge technologies to create carbon nanotube transistors with high quality gate oxide, a major step towards development of deeply scaled Si ICs.  For translational research, our staff supported a major NASA project led by a team including UC Irvine, UCLA, JPL, and Cal Poly to advance the technology of impulse electrospray thrusters for SmallSat propulsion. 

For outreach and STEM education, SDNI organized an education symposium with the theme ?Integrating Nanotechnology Contents with State-Wide K-12 Science Curricula: Challenges and Strategies?. The meeting included presenters from NNCI sites, NNCO, the San Diego County Office of Education, and high schools in Southern California. During the 2-day Zoom meeting, attendees exchanged ideas and collaboration plans to promote STEM in K-12. Because of the positive response and high enthusiasm, the second outreach and education conference will be organized next year.

Being an active member of the RAIN network, SDNI has offered remote SEM tutorials and lab sections to enable nanostructure visualization as an effective means to introduce nanotechnology and STEM subjects to K-12 students with an expanding geographic coverage to Northern California and Oregon. With creativity and strong supports from faculty and graduate student mentors, SDNI created a pilot REU program with REU students located in 8 cities and 5 states of the country.  The program included lecture series by world class nanotechnology experts, projects with AI, entrepreneurship education sessions, academic development program, and team projects. SDNI also organized Nanotechnology Summer Institute for Middle and High School Teachers for teachers to learn nanotechnologies and to develop a NGSS-aligned lesson plan which they can bring to their class. SDNI also developed the first Integrated Photonic Education Kit (IPEK) as a plug & play education tool for people having broad interests in photonic applications (e.g. sensing, communications, robotics, autonomous driving, imaging, holography, etc.) to facilitate and encourage convergence research and to promote STEM education at the undergraduate and graduate level.

 


Last Modified: 01/13/2022
Modified by: Yu-Hwa Lo
